title: Former Kurdish-led fighters and Damascus test a fragile 'reconciliation' in northeastern Syria
subhed: After retaking the provinces of Deir ez-Zor, Raqqa and Hassakeh, Syria's transitional authorities opened reconciliation centers for former fighters from the Kurdish-led Syrian Democratic Forces to surrender their weapons.
byline: By Hélène Sallon (Deir ez-Zor (Syria), special correspondent)

title: After Trump's warning, Iran threatens to hit US bases and carriers in event of attack
Trump's new Minneapolis point man vows 'smarter' operation
'Europe's housing crisis is a democratic time bomb'
subhed: Young people across many European regions are struggling to access decent housing, observes Marie Charrel in her column. The difficulties and frustrations this causes have clear political consequences.

title: Morocco unveils plans for a giant film city on the outskirts of Rabat
subhed: Extra-large studios are set to be built as early as this year near Morocco's capital. Streaming giants such as Netflix, Prime Video and Disney have shown interest in the venture, which is being spearheaded by Khadija Alami, the Moroccan executive producer behind the local shoots of the series 'Homeland' and 'Prison Break.'

title: Brazil's highly politicized and polarized wardrobes
subhed: With just months to go before the presidential election, wearing a particular brand of flip-flops or a certain football shirt has come to signify political allegiance. Many Brazilians have pushed back against these controversies and have refused to let their clothing choices be dictated.
byline: By Anne-Dominique Correa (Rio de Janeiro, correspondent)

title: 'The only thing left to do is leave': Cuba pushed to the brink
subhed: 'Cuba, an island adrift' (2/3). Since the wave of unrest that swept the country in 2021, more than two million Cubans have fled. Those who remain on the island scrape by with varying degrees of success, as the exorbitant price of basic goods has become a source of inequality between those with nothing and those with access to foreign currency.

'For sure': Two impromptu words by Macron go viral
subhed: During his speech at the World Economic Forum in Davos, the French president delivered a common English phrase – in a strong accent – that achieved global fame.

title: Why there are so many French presidential hopefuls
subhed: As a result of political fragmentation, the growing number of figures who have declared their candidacies or are thinking about doing so is making the 2027 presidential election highly uncertain, writes Le Monde's Solenn de Royer in her column.

title: Veteran civil servant Xavier Piechaczyk to head Paris public transports
subhed: France's Parliament approved President Emmanuel Macron's nominee to head the RATP on Wednesday. The appointment now awaits formal confirmation by decree.

Europe: 'A new social federalism must be invented as the response of democratic states to empires'
